awd_titl_txt: RUI: Studies of Condensed-Phase Effects on the Structural Properties of Molecular Complexes
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms A Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor James Phillips and his undergraduate research students seek to understand how two interacting molecules (a molecular complex) may change their structure or the nature of their interaction depending on whether they are in the gas phase (i.e., surrounded by essentially nothing), or in the condensed phase (surrounded by solvent molecules or other molecular complexes). The Phillips' research group uses infrared spectroscopy to probe the vibrational motions of molecular complexes in different environments at low temperatures (5 to 100 Kelvin, or -450 to -280 Fahrenheit).  The team is also performing theoretical calculations (quantum chemistry models) to further understand the experimental observations.  The University of Wisconsin - Eau Claire is a low-cost, public institution with a student body that is about 60% female and 50% low-income/first generation students.  This research program actively involves these underrepresented groups.  Moreover, the Chemistry Department at the University of Wisconsin - Eau Claire has embarked upon an integrated effort to actively recruit students from underrepresented groups, based in part on an NSF-Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site. 

The intellectual goals of the project are twofold, and are pursued through a combination of experiments and modeling. From a fundamental standpoint, the aim is to identify and characterize systems prone to condensed-phase structural change, and thereby challenge long-held, fundamental principles of chemical bonding. Specific systems that are studied in this regard are imine-HCl complexes, which offer snapshots of an acid-base reaction in progress; as well as carbon monoxide-BX3 complexes (X = F, Cl, Br), for which theory predicts two distinct, stable structures with different bond distances. Additional target systems have potential applications, because the ability to manipulate a chemical structure via some external stimulus is the key underlying design feature for any nanotechnology device. Complexes involving nitrogen donors (e.g., pyridine, C5H5N) with Group IV metal acceptors (MX3R: M = silicon, germanium;  X = fluorine, chlorine; R = carbon-based group) have the desired molecular architecture for such applications.  The first step towards gauging their suitability is to assess their tendency to undergo structural change.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the project was to identify and characterize molecular complexes - associations of two stable molecules, a "donor" and an "acceptor", which may be apt to bond to one another - in search of systems that exhibit unusual structural properties, including:

i) A tendency to undergo major structural changes between different chemical environments (i.e., gas vs. solution), and,
 
ii) Theoccurance of two distinct structural forms that differ mainly in the length of a specific bond.

The latter refers to a controversial phenomenon often labeled "bond-stretch isomerism". A secondary goal was to pursue systems with that may be advantageous for materials chemistry and nanotechnology applications.

We explored these complexes using both experiments and chemical theory (i.e., computer simulations of the bonding). For the experiments, we prepared and trapped the systems  in "cryogenic inert-gas matrices" - samples of frozen noble gases at temperatures near absolute zero. Then we measured the resonant frequencies of component molecules unsing infrared spectrscopy. Many of these frequencies shift as the complex is formed, and the shifts get more extreme as the donor-acceptor bond contracts and strengthens. The theoretical studies compliment these observations by providing a key conceptual link to specific structural information (i.e., specific values for bond lengths and angles), and also provide mechanistic insight as to the underlying causes of these phenomena.

As for identifying systems apt to change structure in chemical environments, we successfully completed studies of several complexes involving pyridine (C5H5N) or fluorinated pyridines (e.g., F2C5H3N) "donors" with various "MX4 acceptors" (e.g., GeCl4, SiCl4, SiF4). Of these, the SiF4 systems (e.g., F2C5H3N–SiF4) show definitive signs of N-Si bond contraction in the inert matrices. The effects are subtle, but this is only the second class of systems that we have observed this for (among many, in over 15 years of research). The GeCl4 and SiCl4 systems do not show such effects, but we did note the key underlying energetic feature in the theoretical data.

We also explored another, slightly different class of complexes that exhibit a significant type of structural change in the inert media, which amounts to an acid-base reaction. These systems are comprised of pyridine and the fluoropyridines (noted above) with HCl (e.g., F2C5H3N–HCl). We subsequently explored the analogous HBr (e.g., FC5H4N–HBr) and HF (e.g., F5C5N–HF) systems as well. What we found was that in some cases, the inert media provided just enough of a solvent effect to cause the hydrogen atom to transfer from the HX to the pyridine ? a solvent induced an acid-base reaction (by a very inert solvent!). Moreover, we could adjust the strength of the complex itself and the degree of solvation effect necessary for the reaction via the number of fluorines on the pyridine subunit, which varied between HF, HCl, and HBr.

We also explored a series of complexes comprised on nitrogen donors and so-called "MX3R" acceptors (e.g., H3N–SiCl3CH3), in hopes that these would not only show medium sensitivity, but also be amenable to materials chemistry applications. The key here is that the bond contraction would occur within a structural motif that could be built into a larger molecular assembly, and the effect would enable controllable motion at the molecular level. As it turns out, the energetically optimal structures in these systems are not the proper orientation, but we were able to identify potential modifications to these structures for future inquires which would render them more apt.

As for the bond length isomers, we had correctly hypothesized that the nature of the interactions in CO complexes with BCl3 and BBr3. However, though we had predicted distinct "long-bond" and "short-bond" structures for both OC–BBr3 and OC–BCl3 using high-level theory, we were unable to confirm these predictions via experiments.

Beyond scientific outcomes, the educational impacts of this research program are of particular note. One factor that amplifies these impacts is that UWEC is a low-cost public institution, for which over 60% of the student body is female, and roughly a third is low-income/first generation students. Specifically, this award enabled the PI to host and mentor students in our NSF-REU and "WisCAMP" programs, which are designed to facillitate recruitment, retention, and subsequent success of minority students. In total, the group published five papers during this award, with 19 undergraduate co-author citations. Moreover, Phillips group students gave a total of 27 off-campus presentations at regional and national conferences. So, beyond the hands-on experience with sophisticated equipment and modern computational techniques, far above and beyond what students are exposed to in their coursework, Phillips group students were compelled to develop their communication skills, and are offered numerous opportunities to present their research and network with their peers as well as experts in the field. These are experiences and accomplishments are nothing short of transformative for these students at this stage of their careers.
